page.title: 02SITE OF BLEASBY
page.content: As the rushing water from the melted ice slowed down sand and gravel were deposited on the trench bottom.Shrewd early man built his dwellings on the higher deposits to avoid being flooded when the River was high.Thus{Bleasby {settlement},in common with a string of riverside villages along this part of the{Trent},was established. This higher area is still occupied by the centre of the village:church, vicarage ,Hall,pub and many older houses. During the last 100 years the land between this old village and the{ {Railway Station},still called Notown , which is not surprising since it was subject to periodic flooding,has been filled up with two small estates and roadside housing.The total{population} is now 700. S.W. towards the River is {Gibsmere}and 1/4 of a mile the other way,towards{Thurgarton},is{Goverton.
